Hospitalization Record.Chief Complaint: Sour, heavy, swollen, and painful right lower limb for 6 months; worsening over the last week.

Present Illness.Onset: 6 months ago, at home, gradual onset with no identifiable triggers
Present Illness.Main Symptoms: Pain, heaviness, and swelling in the right lower limb, with raised and tortuous superficial veins, more pronounced when standing; symptoms exacerbate with prolonged standing and improve with leg elevation
Present Illness.Accompanying Symptoms: Increased fatigue and weakness in the affected limb, mild itching around the swollen veins
Present Illness.Diagnosis and Treatment History: Patient had a Doppler ultrasound done at the local clinic, which showed severe blood reflux in superficial veins; compression stockings were prescribed but provided minimal relief
Present Illness.General Condition Changes: No significant changes in mental state or sleep. Appetite has been slightly reduced due to discomfort. Regular urination and bowel movements. Mild weight loss noted

Past History.Disease History: Hypertension for 20 years, controlled with medication. Osteoarthritis in knees
Past History.Immunization History: Up-to-date with routine vaccinations. Received influenza vaccine last fall
Past History.Surgery and Trauma History: Cholecystectomy 15 years ago. No significant trauma history

Personal History.Living Habits: Non-smoker, occasional glass of wine. Eats a balanced diet, limited exercise due to arthritis
Personal History.Exposure History: No significant exposure to industrial toxins, dust, or radioactive substances

Marital History.Children's Condition: Two children, both in good health

Marital and Family History.Family History: Mother had varicose veins, father had hypertension; no other significant family history

Systematic Examination.Skin: Normal color, warm and dry, no lesions
Systematic Examination.Chest: Thorax normal in shape, lungs clear on auscultation, heart sounds normal without murmurs
Systematic Examination.Limbs: Right lower limb shows raised, tortuous, varicose veins; mild edema; no ulcers. Left limb normal

Hospitalization Record.Specialist Examination: Right lower limb with visible, tortuous, dilated superficial veins, positive Trendelenburg test
Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination: Doppler ultrasound confirmed severe blood reflux in superficial veins of the right lower limb
Hospitalization Record.Preliminary Diagnosis: Varicose Veins of the Lower Leg (Right)
Hospitalization Record.Diagnostic Basis: Typical symptoms of pain, heaviness, and swollen limb with visible varicose veins and confirmed Doppler findings

Differential Diagnosis.Post-thrombotic Syndrome: R/o based on Doppler ultrasound indicating superficial vein involvement without deep vein reflux
Differential Diagnosis.Budd-Chiari Syndrome: R/o due to absence of ascites and hepatosplenomegaly
Differential Diagnosis.Klippel-Trenaunay Syndrome: R/o as there is no limb hypertrophy or cutaneous hemangioma

Post-Admission Course Records.First Course Record: Patient presents with symptoms characteristic of right lower limb varicose veins. Initial management plan includes continued use of compression stockings, limb elevation, and referral to vascular surgery for evaluation of sclerotherapy. Pain management with NSAIDs as needed. Regular follow-up scheduled.
Post-Admission Course Records.Daily Course Records: Symptomatic relief noted with regular use of compression stockings. Pain has reduced marginally. No signs of thrombophlebitis.
Post-Admission Course Records.Senior Physician Rounds Records: Patient stable, conservative management continues. Discussed potential need for surgical intervention if symptoms persist. Plan to monitor for next 48 hours.
Post-Admission Course Records.Handover Records: Patient stable, continue current management, re-evaluate in morning rounds.
Post-Admission Course Records.Stage Summary: Patient shows mild improvement with conservative management. Vascular surgery consult pending. Discharge planning will depend on surgical opinion.

Medical Orders.Long-term Orders:
1. Compression stockings to be worn daily 
2. Elevate right leg when sitting or lying
3. Ibuprofen 200 mg orally every 6 hours as needed for pain
Medical Orders.Temporary Orders:
1. Vascular surgery consultation
2. Doppler ultrasound repeat if condition worsens

Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination Reports: Doppler ultrasound report showing severe blood reflux in the superficial veins of the right lower limb
Hospitalization Record.Temperature Chart: Temperature: 36.8°C, Pulse: 78 bpm, Respiration: 18 breaths/min, Blood Pressure: 140/85 mmHg

Circulatory System Diseases.Name: Varicose Veins of the Lower Leg
Circulatory System Diseases.Symptoms: The affected limb often feels sour, heavy, swollen, and painful, and is prone to fatigue and weakness; the superficial veins of the affected limb are raised, dilated, and become tortuous, even winding or in lumps, which is more obvious when standing
Circulatory System Diseases.Differential Diagnosis: Post-thrombotic syndrome of the lower limbs (Doppler ultrasound suggests poor blood reflux in the deep veins, with simultaneous blood backflow. Lower limb venography shows rough deep vein walls, and the venous lumen is irregularly narrowed), Budd-Chiari Syndrome (enlarged spleen, large and stubborn ascites), Klippel-Trenaunay Syndrome (limb growth, thickening, abnormally large and tortuous superficial veins, and the triad of cutaneous hemangioma)

qa_summary.question: According to the hospitalization records of Kingsport General Hospital, summarize the present illness of A. Davis.
qa_summary.answer: A. Davis's present illness began 6 months ago at home with a gradual onset and no identifiable triggers. She experiences pain, heaviness, and swelling in the right lower limb, with raised and tortuous superficial veins, more pronounced when standing. Symptoms exacerbate with prolonged standing and improve with leg elevation. Accompanying symptoms include increased fatigue and weakness in the affected limb and mild itching around the swollen veins. A Doppler ultrasound showed severe blood reflux in superficial veins, and compression stockings provided minimal relief. There have been no significant changes in mental state or sleep, a slight reduction in appetite due to discomfort, regular urination and bowel movements, and mild weight loss.
